The investigators form a "Mathematics and Climate Research
Network." This is a framework for an intensive effort aimed at
bringing to bear the full power of modern applied mathematics and
statistics on the prediction and understanding of the Earth's
climate. The investigators focus on three key themes: (1)
Dynamics of Climate, (2) Climate Process Modeling, and (3) Data
Analysis and Data Assimilation. Dynamics of Climate addresses
critical climate processes and their interactions. Climate
Process Modeling undertakes the modeling of climate components
that have been underrepresented in extant climate models, such as
the multi-scale material structure of sea ice. Data Analysis and
Data Assimilation develops mathematical tools for analyzing
climate data and assimilating them in current climate models.
The Research Network aims to be a national resource, with
participants at thirteen U.S. universities. The investigators
work together as a virtual community that holds regular weekly
"webinars" and working meetings over the Internet. This
multi-year effort is expected to help in defining a research area
of "climate mathematics" and in educating a new generation of
mathematical researchers to meet the scientific challenges
associated with a changing climate.

This project is driven by the need to better understand the
Earth's climate system. Climate is the result of many
geophysical and chemical processes in the Earth's atmosphere,
oceans and biosphere. These processes evolve in time over many
scales, ranging from minutes to centuries, and interact in
multiple ways, most often nonlinearly. Feedback mechanisms, many
of which are poorly understood, further complicate the picture.
Because there is only one Earth, climate cannot be studied by
systematic experimentation; the only approach available to
climate researchers is through computational experiments. These
experiments are based on mathematical models, which must be
simple enough not to exceed the capabilities of today's advanced
computer architectures, while still incorporating the physical
and chemical processes that are essential for realistic climate
outcomes. The expertise of mathematical scientists in designing,
assessing and interpreting these models is critical. This
"Mathematics and Climate Research Network" helps engage the
mathematical sciences community to address the mathematical and
statistical issues of our changing climate. The Research Network
takes full advantage of current information technology;
communication and collaboration among the participants takes
place mostly remotely over the Internet.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is part of a large collaborative effort, the Mathematics & Climate Research Network (MCRN), which seeks to recruit talented young scientists to work on problems relating to Earth's changing environment. At UVM, we are developing (1) new methods for quantifying the state of the Earth's atmosphere accurately, and building new instruments that measure (2) changes in temperature extremes & (3) public opinion. Details on the work can be found in publications listed above, but the main findings supported by the grant are summarized below.

(1) The first component of this project facilitates the development of methods for increasing the accuracy of forecasts made by computer models of the weather and climate. We use simple models of the Earth's atmosphere, as well as laboratory based fluid dynamics experiments, to develop improvements to data assimilation and ensemble forecasting algorithms. These algorithms enable accurate estimates of the state of the Earth's atmosphere, and probabilistic forecasts of its future state. In one study, we built a thermal convection loop and conducted a series of experiments forecasting the flow using Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) simulations, identifying the spatial density and temporal frequency of experimental observations required to synchronize a CFD simulation to a reference truth. In another study, we developed a method for using observational data to improve a numerical model via parameter estimation, in the case where the parameter to be estimated varies in both space and time. This problem is particularly relevant in weather and climate prediction, where important processes in the model such as convection, are known to be very different in different regions, e.g. in the mid-latitudes compared to the tropics. 

(2) Instabilities and long term shifts in seasons, whether induced by natural drivers or human activities, pose great disruptive threats to ecological, agricultural, and social systems. In another study, we proposed two fundamental markers of seasonal variations: the Summer and Winter Teletherms---the on-average annual dates of the hottest and coldest days of the year. We analyzed daily temperature extremes recorded at 1218 stations across the contiguous United States from 1853--2012 to obtain estimates of the Teletherms, and to characterize their spatial and temporal dynamics. We found substantial regional variation with the Summer Teletherm falling up to 90 days after the Summer Solstice, and 50 days for the Winter Teletherm after the Winter Solstice. We show Teletherm temporal dynamics are substantive with clear and in some cases dramatic changes moving across broad regions, suggesting links to climate change. We also compare recorded daily temperature extremes with output from two weather models in an attempt to suggest areas of improvement in model predictions. We plan to continue this work by extending the results beyond the US to global data for over 100,000 stations worldwide.


(3) Since 2008, our research group has received Twitter's garden-hose feed, a random 10% of all tweets, processing roughly 50 million messages (150GB) daily. The collection now comprises nearly 300TB of uncompressed text, representing over 100 billion messages. Using this unique dataset, we're studying human behavior in response to the exogenous shocks often produced by world events, natural disasters, and climate change. Three of our major observations are that appropriately filtered Twitter sentiment (a) suggests that responses to climate change news are predominately from climate change activists, (b) predicts President Obama’s job approval three months in advance, and (c) correlates well with traditionally surveyed consumer sentiment. To make possible a full examination of our work and to enable others’ research, we have made public a massive data set consisting of 10,000 terms, each a seven-year series of daily word counts for tweets containing a frequently used search term. Solicited public opinion surveys reach a limited subpopulation of willing participants and are expensive to conduct, leading to poor time resolution and a restricted pool of expert-chosen survey topics. In this project, we have demonstrated that unsolicited public opinion polling through sentiment analysis applied to Twitter correlates well with a range of traditional measures, and has predictive power for issues of global importance.
